title: ICASSP_1997_706_abs

sentences.text: Utterance Verification -LRB- UV -RRB- is a critical function of an Automatic Speech Recognition -LRB- ASR -RRB- System working on real applications where spontaneous speech , out-of-vocabulary -LRB- OOV -RRB- words and acoustic noises are present .

In this paper we present a new UV procedure with two major features : a -RRB- Confidence tests are applied to decoded string hypotheses obtained from using word and garbage models that represent OOV words and noises .
Thus the ASR system is designed to deal with what we refer to as Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities .
b -RRB- The UV procedure is based on three different confidence tests , two based on acoustic measures and one founded on linguistic information , applied in a hierarchical structure .

Experimental results from a real telephone application on a natural number recognition task show an 50 % reduction in recognition errors with a moderate 12 % rejection rate of correct utterances and a low 1.5 % rate of false acceptance .

Entity-utterance_verification_-lrb-_uv_-.label: Utterance Verification -LRB- UV -RRB-
Entity-utterance_verification_-lrb-_uv_-.description: A technique for verifying utterances in Automatic Speech Recognition systems, designed to handle spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noises.

Entity-the_uv_procedure_is_based_on_thre.label: The UV procedure is based on three different confidence tests, two based on acoustic measures and one founded on linguistic information, applied in a hierarchical structure

Entity-the_uv_procedure_is_based_on_thre.description: A speech recognition system verification process that uses three types of confidence tests: two based on acoustic measurements and one based on linguistic analysis, organized in a hierarchical structure.

Entity-a_new_uv_procedure.description: A novel approach for verifying utterances, featuring two major components: confidence tests applied to decoded string hypotheses representing out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises.

Entity-50__reduction_in_recognition_erro.label: 50 % reduction in recognition errors
Entity-50__reduction_in_recognition_erro.description: The result of applying an Utterance Verification procedure to a natural number recognition task in a real telephone application, showing a reduction by half in errors.

Entity-two_major_feature.description: A new Utterance Verification procedure with two major features: a confidence test for decoding string hypotheses representing out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises, and another feature based on linguistic information.

Entity-the_asr_system.description: An Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system designed for real-world applications, capable of dealing with spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noises through Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities.

summary: Utterance Verification -LRB- UV -RRB- is a critical function of an Automatic Speech Recognition -LRB- ASR -RRB- System working on real applications where spontaneous speech , out-of-vocabulary -LRB- OOV -RRB- words and acoustic noises are present . In this paper we present a new UV procedure with two major features : a -RRB- Confidence tests are applied to decoded string hypotheses obtained from using word and garbage models that represent OOV words and noises . Thus the ASR system is designed to deal with what we refer to as Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities . b -RRB- The UV procedure is based on three different confidence tests , two based on acoustic measures and one founded on linguistic information , applied in a hierarchical structure . Experimental results from a real telephone application on a natural number recognition task show an 50 % reduction in recognition errors with a moderate 12 % rejection rate of correct utterances and a low 1.5 % rate of false acceptance .

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that the subject (in this case, a new UV procedure) exhibits or displays the object (two major features), suggesting a state of being where these features are inherent to or characteristic of the subject.

Predicate-are_used_for.label: are used for
Predicate-are_used_for.description: The predicate 'are used for' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject serves as a means or tool to achieve some purpose or goal, which is described by the object. In general, this predicate suggests that the subject plays an instrumental role in accomplishing something related to the object.

Predicate-is_designed_to_deal_with.label: is designed to deal with
Predicate-is_designed_to_deal_with.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (e.g., an entity or system) has been intentionally created or developed to handle, manage, or address specific challenges, tasks, or situations represented by its object. The connection between the subject and object is one of purposeful design, implying that the subject's primary function or capability is geared towards dealing with the specified issue or problem.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or has its foundation in the object. It suggests that the subject's existence, validity, or effectiveness is grounded in or derived from the information, principles, or methods described by the object.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control over, responsibility for, or ownership of the object, which can be an abstract concept, task, property, or entity.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates an identification or equivalence relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses or embodies the characteristics described by the object, which can be a description, definition, classification, or other type of characterization.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a specific instance or member of a more general category or class represented by the object. It establishes a hierarchical relationship between the two, where the subject is a narrower or more specialized version of the object.
